metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax v. Insurance Company

facts.text: The respondent is a company carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business.
The dispute relates to assessment of excess profits tax on income from business other than life insurance for chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940, and December 31, 1941.
Insurance policies concerned are issued for short periods or ad hoc; fire policies normally for one year; whole premium received upfront.
In any year, premiums received in full but risks covered only in part; part outstanding for next year.
Respondent's accounting method: premiums fully included in assets; 40% treated as reserve for unexpired risks shown as liability; balance in net profits.
Example: In 1939, Rs. 1,00,000 premiums received; Rs. 40,000 shown as reserve for unexpired risks; in 1940, that reserve becomes asset.
This method adopted by insurance companies per approved accountancy practice.
High Court of Calcutta on reference under s.66(1) Income-tax Act read with s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act answered adversely to appellant; granted certificate under s.66A.
Statements to Controller of Insurance disclosed 40% premiums as reserve for unexpired risks, treated as liability in P&L, allowed in income-tax assessment.

legal_issues.text: Whether amounts shown by insurance company as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r.2 of Sch.II to the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 from capital employed.

petitioner_arguments.text: All premiums received treated as capital under r.1 Sch.II; reserves for unexpired risks (e.g. Rs.40,000) represent outstanding liability, deductible as accruing liability under r.2 Sch.II.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act; Sun Insurance Office v. Clark

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract of insurance complete on policy issue; risk attaches; liability accruing as long as policy in force; can ripen anytime.

respondent_arguments.text: Provision for unexpired risks is contingent liability, not within r.2 Sch.II.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Contract Act s.31; history of r.2 amendment

respondent_arguments.text: Insurance contract contingent until event happens; no enforceable liability; not a debt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Webb v. Stenton; Israelson v. Dawson

court_reasoning.text: One condition for r.2 satisfied as reserves allowed in income-tax computation per r.6 Sch. Income-tax Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute on whether reserve is sum in respect of accruing liability.

court_reasoning.text: Sun Insurance allows deduction for income-tax as present liability/unearned premium, but Excess Profits Tax differs; capital under Sch.II factual, includes all assets utilised in business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: r.2 deductions (borrowed money, debts, accruing liabilities) must be profit-earning assets utilised in business.

court_reasoning.text: Reserve for unexpired risks not real trading asset contributing to profits; something in the air, no effect on business working.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not accruing liability per r.2 Sch.II.

court_reasoning.text: Northern Aluminium case applies: contingent liability not accruing for Excess Profits Tax, even if allowed for income-tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No difference if from insurance policy.

holdings.text: Reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are not sums in respect of accruing liabilities deductible under r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act.

precedents_cited.treatment: followed for income-tax; distinguished for excess profits tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Allows deduction of unexpired risks reserve as present liability/unearned premium for income-tax purposes.

precedents_cited.case_name: The General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v. McGowan
precedents_cited.relevance: Turned on facts; not barring deduction as matter of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents_cited.relevance: Receipts not profits until cost of earning deducted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Scottish Union and National Insurance Company v. Smiles
precedents_cited.relevance: No allowance for unexpired risks; not reliable per Lord Haldane.
Debt is debitum in praesenti, solvendum in futuro.

precedents_cited.case_name: Israelson v. Dawson (Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees)
precedents_cited.relevance: Amount under policy not debt until compensation determined.

precedents_cited.case_name: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes contingent liability from payment on contingency; insurance liability present.

precedents_cited.case_name: Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents_cited.relevance: Conditional liability not accruing for excess profits tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Affirms no accruing liability for conditional obligations in excess profits tax.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge on excess profits; standard profits on capital employed; rules for capital include assets minus borrowed money/debts/accruing liabilities.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Profits of non-life insurance per annual accounts under Insurance Act, adjusted; reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires annual accounts furnished to Controller of Insurance.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended r.2 Sch.II to include accruing liabilities within debts.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed; reserves for unexpired risks not deductible under r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act as accruing liabilities.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; upholds High Court in favor of respondent.

key_quotes.text: "The debts to be deducted under this sub-rule shall include any such sums in respect of accruing liabilities as are allowable as a deduction in computing profits for the purposes of excess profits tax"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "a purely contingent liability, which may or may not mature, is not one which falls within that language... it would be contrary to the whole conception underlying these capital provisions"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Northern Aluminium; crux why reserve not accruing liability.

key_quotes.text: "The reserve liability could not factually be said to have contributed to the running of the business or the earning of profits. It was something in the air"
key_quotes.speaker: court
